qas.question: What was measured in the early 20th century?
What did Carl von Voit and Max Rubner apply to nutrition in order to receive their results?
Which amino acid can assist with the well - being of mice but not necessarily their growth?
What did Hopkins believe was required other than calories, protein and minerals to help prevent deficiency diseases?
Which experiment related to diet was conducted that required four years to complete?

context: In the early 20th century, Carl von Voit and Max Rubner independently measured <a0_0>caloric energy expenditure<a0_0/> in different species of animals, applying <a1_0>principles of physics<a1_0/> in nutrition. In 1906, Edith G. Willcock and Frederick Hopkins showed that the amino acid <a2_0>tryptophan<a2_0/> aids the well-being of mice but it did not assure their growth. In the middle of twelve years of attempts to isolate them, Hopkins said in a 1906 lecture that "<a3_0>unsuspected dietetic factors<a3_0/>," other than calories, protein, and minerals, are needed to prevent deficiency diseases. In 1907, Stephen M. Babcock and Edwin B. Hart conducted the <a4_0>single-grain experiment<a4_0/>, which took nearly four years to complete.
